misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Prompt text changes program behavior / computer “understands” the English prompt
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that writing a prompt like "Enter miles per gallon:" somehow tells Java what kind of value is expected and helps ensure the user inputs the correct thing (i.e., the prompt itself enforces meaning/validation).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, prompt strings are only text sent to the console. They do not constrain input or give the program semantic understanding of what the user typed. Only the code that reads/parses input (e.g., nextDouble) determines what will be accepted, and without explicit validation the program will crash or behave unexpectedly if the user types something non-numeric or the wrong units.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Potential runtime exception (InputMismatchException) or incorrect results if user enters unexpected units/format; no automatic validation occurs.

evidence.code_snippet: System.out.print("Enter the driving distance in miles: ");

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Overgeneralizing numeric types: assuming decimals are always handled correctly without edge cases (e.g., zero, formatting)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because they used double, the computation will always be mathematically valid and produce a sensible money value.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: While double allows fractional input, Java will still happily compute Infinity/NaN (e.g., if mpg is 0) and will print many digits for floating-point values. Money typically needs rounding/formatting, which Java does not do automatically. Also, floating-point precision can produce slightly-off decimal representations.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Possible output of Infinity/NaN (if mpg==0), or overly long/odd-looking decimals for currency; small precision errors.

evidence.code_snippet: System.out.println("The cost of driving is $" + cost);
